subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] On a keyboard
msgSnippet:
The Model-M was IBM s main line of keyboards back when IBM over
engineered everything, it was used on dumb terminals and PCs mostly,
it s built like a tank,
messageBody:
The Model-M was IBM's main line of keyboards back when IBM over
engineered everything, it was used on dumb terminals and PCs mostly,
it's built like a tank, weighs a ton, every part is replaceable and it
can survive just about any abuse you throw at it.
I figured if you're going to get a keyboard which isn't easily
replaceable you want one which isn't easily breakable :).

There's a frequency chart in the files section.

Jean-François Colson wrote:
>
> amd64_hacker wrote:
> > http://www.pckeyboard.com/Kustomizing.html
> <http://www.pckeyboard.com/Kustomizing.html> - The site of Unicomp.
> > They inherited the Model M, the classic PC keyboard, from IBM.
>
> What's the Model M?
>
> > They're a bit costly but they last forever.
> > They want 'certain volume requirements' for 'unique keyboards' though.
> >
> > Does anyone else know of any other custom keyboard manufacturers?
>
> There's a very interesting keyboard project known as Optimus
> (http://www.artlebedev.org/portfolio/optimus/
> <http://www.artlebedev.org/portfolio/optimus/>) which would be
> released in the end of 2006.
>
> > What sort of layout should a QS keyboard have anyway?
>
> Let's take a very wide text written in QS and estimate the frequency
> of each character. After that it would be relatively easy to make a
> Dvorak QS keyboard for English.
>
> >
> > tim_rice09 wrote:
> > >
> > > The keyboard that we use now was designed for a 26 letter alphabet
> > > and the current way to write Quickscript uses the shift keys about as
> > > much as the spacebar.
>
> On my keyboard there are 48 alphanumeric keys. On yours, perhaps 47.
> On Brazilian keyboards, 49.
> Even 47 keys would be enough for Junior QS. For Senior QS a tool such
> as Keyman could be interesting.
>
> > > Not to mention the backspace key takes a finger
> > > contortionism to use.
>
> The BS key? It's at the upper right corner of all keyboards I know of.
>
> > > A possible answer to this, build a new keyboard that may not even
> > > have to have a shift key.
> > >
> > >
>
>
